author: Ronnie Wachter
title: Medical marijuana shop coming to Buffalo Grove next month - Buffalo Grove Countryside
text:
Buffalo Grove could have its first medical marijuana dispensary as soon as next month, officials said this week.
The dispensary is scheduled to open in November, possibly around Thanksgiving, at 1623 Barclay Boulevard, according to a spokeswoman for Professional Dispensaries of Illinois. The company is in the middle of converting the existing storefront to meet state safety requirements.
"With this industry, there's a lot" of those safety mandates, said Beth Strautz, PDI's spokeswoman.
The proposed location has a home medical-equipment provider nearby, and it's just west of the Regal Cinemas Lincolnshire 21.
According to a statement from the company, PDI "will offer pharmaceutical-grade cannabis products including edibles, tinctures, concentrates, and buds. In addition, staff members will walk patients through the Illinois Medical Cannabis Card application process, from filling out forms to providing state-authorized fingerprinting and passport photo services."
The statement said the CEO of the newly formed company is Dr. Mark Mandel, owner of Mark Drugs, a 30-year-old compounding pharmacy with locations in Deerfield and Roselle. Another licensed pharmacist, Joseph Friedman, is working as chief operations officer.

This is the second medicinal marijuana outlet to approach Buffalo Grove.
The first, a Gurnee-based group called Midwest Releaf, spoke with the Village Board in summer 2014 about setting up shop in the property immediately south of PDI's proposed location, at 1477 Barclay Boulevard.
Both Midwest Releaf and PDI met the requirements of the state's Medical Cannabis Pilot Program, but after Releaf's officials met with Buffalo Grove's trustees, they discovered that the price of refurbishing the building they had selected was more than they could afford.
Illinois law requires a dispensary to have high-definition security cameras, bulletproof glass, advanced locks and more. In September 2014, Releaf announced that it had abandoned its plan for Buffalo Grove because of the location's build-out cost.
On Thursday, Village President Beverly Sussman said price did not appear to be any kind of hindrance for PDI.

Deputy Police Chief Roy Bethge said Friday his department's leaders had sat down with PDI officials, and that they were as satisfied with the coming business as they could be.
"We're confident that, if they do everything they have presented in their plan, that everything will be secure," Bethge said. "There's a lot of what-ifs in that question."
